text: Worth noting that Ms. Ross makes no effort whatsoever to suggest that Jackson was innocent of the crimes ascribed to him.
author: OrrChris

text: No he would not. The only reason he's VP is that he was about to lose a statewide race in Indiana as a Republican, which is flat-out sad. He'd oversee a fractured, wounded party in which no one on either side of the aisle would fear him in the least.
author: OrrChris

text: I said nothing remotely along those lines. Perhaps you missed "hopelessly fractured," "ineffectual," "loses in landslide"?
author: OrrChris

text:
19 hours and counting.

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/with_replies …
author: OrrChris

text: Plus, however bad he is as president, Pence is not a wold-historically ignorant, narcissistic, impulsive, juvenile bully whose primary goals in life are enriching himself at public expense and humiliating others publicly.
author: OrrChris

text: In this scenario, GOP is hopelessly fractured. Loyal Trump voters hate Pence and GOP almost as much as Dems. Pence (who would have come in 18th if he'd run in 2016) is hopelessly ineffectual and loses in landslide if he makes it past primaries.
author: OrrChris

text: Took some sleuthing, but I've obtained a draft of the Miller Report. Analysis TK, as soon as I can find my Cliff's Notes.

text: Someone will bust his/her ass to get the next story, even if it's just procedural. Everyone else will have to bust their asses catching up. Bad weekend to be on legal/political news beats.

text: "Little upside." This is what happens when the members of a political party lose sight of any goal beyond maintaining power, both individually and collectively.

text: How is it that no one saw that Mike Gravel getting into the 2020 race was the single most foreordained event of the cycle?
author: OrrChris

text: Steph understandably gets most of the credit. But Steve Kerr is the other reason it is almost impossible to dislike the Warriors.
author: OrrChris

text: Do Democratic politicians who find themselves in trouble with Democratic electorates really fail to understand that explicitly echoing Donald Trump's language is unlikely to help them?
author: OrrChris

text: Trump met Kellyanne through George, after the latter took Trump's side in a tenant dispute in Trump World Tower. Trump thanked George personally, and he was offered a seat on the condo board. He didn't want it but Kellyanne did, which is how she met Trump. https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/04/kellyannes-alternative-universe/517821/ …
author: OrrChris

text: The summer photo forgot to put in a hurricane.
author: OrrChris

text: Chicago. (Mostly for the big "We Both Reached for the Gun" number)
author: OrrChris

text: No power to be heard because pols won’t campaign there? Already true, and would get better rather than worse w/out EC. Or won’t be heard because they’re minority? I don’t think this is accurate, but if it were, the reason would be “democracy.”
author: OrrChris

text: Also, funny you mention Yellowstone. Nobody (or rather everybody) in Wyoming  owns it--along with every other federal taxpayer. 48 percent of Wyoming is federal land. Why should Wyoming voters have more powerful votes based on an "area" that isn't even theirs?
author: OrrChris

text: You're right. If George Soros had the only vote in all of Wyoming he would doubtless use his extraordinary new national power primarily on local issues.
author: OrrChris

text: Or imagine that Jeff Bezos bought out every single resident of Wyoming for an average of $100,000 apiece and then moved there. Should he personally get 3 EVs? I mean, his "area" would certainly have its own issues and interests.
author: OrrChris

text: No, the sense that the EC is unfair derives from the fact that it *is* unfair: Some Americans' votes count much more than others. Whether or not this disparity more or less balances out in a given election, it is always *unfair* to the underrepresented voters.
author: OrrChris

text: But under what democratic logic should AREAS be represented instead of American voters? Should we give the many sheep in Montana the vote because otherwise that "area" receives inadequate attention? Or the moose in Alaska?
author: OrrChris

text: Your reply makes zero sense. We agree that rural CA voters have no meaningful say in a national election with the EC. Establish majority vote, and every single vote, by definition, counts exactly as much as every single other one.
author: OrrChris

text: Whether or not the state gets extra "attention," every vote cast by someone in Wyoming has greater overall value than every vote cast by someone in California. 193K Wyoming voters account for a single EV. In California, that number is 720K voters.
author: OrrChris

text: This is the precise equivalent of complaining that "candidate x wants to abolish the electoral college, yet she/he continues to campaign heavily in swing states, rather than courting every vote in America equally."
author: OrrChris

text: The perfect coda.
author: OrrChris

text: Thread.
author: OrrChris

text: Also, you're conflating "rural folks" with rural states. The rural voters who have genuine cause to be mad are those in, say, California, whose votes are too meager in state terms for any pol to bother seeking. Abolish EC and their votes matter again.
author: OrrChris

text: None of this has anything to do with EC. I doubt Montana voters are genuinely angry that their votes count more in a presidential election than those of California voters. Now, they may be unaware, but that's hardly an EC problem.
author: OrrChris

text:
I could be wrong, too. But
1) I think if you explicitly said we're tying EC abolishment to maintenance of primary calendar, they'd be pretty psyched.
2) Iowa is about 50/50 urban to rural pop; NH close to 2-to-1. "Urban" means a lot more than "huge, cosmopolitan city."
author: OrrChris

text: Is there any meaningful connection here? What NH and Iowa care most about is the primary schedule and you could keep that as is, even if you abolished EC (which means a lot more to, say, Wyoming).
author: OrrChris

text: I'm not suggesting they'll be between Trumpers and Never-Trumpers. I'm suggesting they'll be between Trumpers who mutually agree to pretend that they were never *really* Trumpers, just loyal (reluctantly!) to the party.
author: OrrChris

text: Could be. But she'll be running for the exit eventually, and when she does, it's hard to see her not trying to use these tweets any way she can.
author: OrrChris

text: But don't you think that this is precisely what 70 percent of GOP operatives and electeds will be doing in one form or another? I think there will be a strong incentive toward "I won't call you out as a shameless liar if you don't call me out as one."
author: OrrChris

text: You write as if you believe she has any credibility to lose (and as if you believe enough people genuinely care--see: Spicer, Sean). If she writes a bestselling Trump tell-all, she'll be everywhere. Also, she'll be forgiven, as the entire GOP will be trying to make the same 180.
author: OrrChris

text: If/when she writes a book, I'd expect it to be the most brutal of brutal tell-alls (with a flimsy, I-tried-my-best-to-curb-the-worst rationale). No matter how much criticism she rightly gets, it'll sell 10 million copies.
author: OrrChris

text: I think some variation on #3 is actually quite plausible. Not anything as direct as "George was speaking for me," but maybe "Do you think I would have let my husband tweet that stuff if I hadn't had deep reservations myself?"
author: OrrChris

text: Wait. You get paid money?
author: OrrChris

text: As it probably apparent, I could do this all day. But let's stop at 10, with the beautiful A Blossom Fell. Happy 100th, Nat. We'll never see your like again. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DVpCPDQ2LjE …
author: OrrChris

text: Looking Back, a 1952 Nat song that has a mood unlike any other I can think of--it sounds almost Sam Cooke-y--especially as it builds.
author: OrrChris

text: Another with a little swing, L-O-V-E, from the album of the 1964 same name, Nat's last. It was recorded shortly after he was diagnosed with lung cancer; he would be dead within a few months.
author: OrrChris

text: A slightly livelier one here, Sweet Lorraine, a song that probably would have been forgotten altogether if not for this version.
author: OrrChris

text: When I Fall in Love was a hit for Doris Day in 1952. Nat made it his own four years later. Like Unforgettable, Nat's daughter Natalie scored a hit with it in the 1990s by re-mixing her dad's version posthumously into a "duet."
author: OrrChris

text: And the companion song (in my mind at least), Pretend. Another standard--Brenda Lee and Marvin Gaye recorded versions--brought most fully to life by Nat.
author: OrrChris

text: Two now that I think of as a pair, due to their thematic similarity. First, Smile. The melody was written by Chaplin for Modern Times in 1936. Nat sang the first version with lyrics (by John Turner and Geoffrey Parsons) in 1954.
author: OrrChris

text: From the same album, Nat's version of Paradise (another standard also recorded by Sinatra, Lena Horne, Bing Crosby, and others). Few singers have ever done so much with so few actual lyrics.
author: OrrChris

text: Another beautiful standard (also recorded by Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra, Dizzy Gillespie, etc), The Very Thought of You, from Nat's album of the same name.
author: OrrChris

text: I'll start with one almost as well known, Nat's version of Stardust, one of the most recorded (>1.5k times, but never better) songs of the 20th century. I sang this to my son nightly when he was a baby.
author: OrrChris

text: On the centenary of Nat King Cole's birth (h/t @nprscottsimon), a few favorites less well-known than Mona Lisa or Unforgettable. Please feel free to retweet.
author: OrrChris

text: Wonderful sentiment. Nat is among the greatest of all-time legends. But I suspect the version you sang with your mom was Nat's, from 1951 (inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2000). The "duet" with Natalie was remixed from that in 1991--26 years after Nat's death.
author: OrrChris

text:
"You're a grown man! You know how to pick up a lobster." 

(Honestly, this thread is pretty great. h/t @NatashaBertrand)
author: OrrChris

text: Works for me too. And the computers seem to be very sophisticated judges of the *level* of obscenity I am employing.
author: OrrChris

text: That makes sense. I think the location of the house is not totally clear, even with the sign, but I'd have to watch again to be sure. Anyway, thanks again for the friendly and informational note. Can't get enough of those, especially on twitter. CO
author: OrrChris

text: Thank you for this. But I didn't say that "countries" weren't cited (I remember they cross into Peru during the escape), but that the location of the heist is unclear. Are you saying it was definitely Brazil? Because neither Peru nor Colombia would make any sense given the title.
author: OrrChris

text: Does it have to be on purpose? Or do accidents count?

text: AMVY was my only number-one, I think, with MG around 2 or 3 and AIL in top 7. Such phenomenal work. Incredible that he's still a virtual unknown among the public.

text: The Eric Trump Foundation is calling on line one...
author: OrrChris

text: Once Sanders and his family are subject to the scrutiny that accompanies most presidential candidacies, I suspect he will take a huge hit in popularity/viability.
author: OrrChris

text: Again: An undercovered aspect of Sanders's candidacies is that--because Hillary anticipated winning and was terrified of infuriating his supporters--he's never taken a meaningful oppo hit. This is especially bad for someone whose public image is based on outsider incorruptability
author: OrrChris

text: Re-upping this thread in light of new NYT story about the Bernie Sanders policy foundation that just stopped paying his wife and son. I suspect there will be plenty more of this yet to come. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/14/us/politics/bernie-sanders-public-policy-group.html …
author: OrrChris

text: I built the Chandor train with my own hands, seeing Margin Call at Nantucket and doing a few Q&As with him. But I do consider AMVY to be his masterpiece (so far). Isaac was basically a better version of young Pacino.
author: OrrChris

text: And then go from that talky, complex multi-star affair to Redford alone in the ocean, and *then* to AMVY, with Oscar Isaac giving one of the very best performances of the last 5 years. Amazing.
author: OrrChris

text: Tom Hanks, Johnny Depp, Will Smith, Channing Tatum, Tom Hardy, Mahershala Ali, and Mark Wahlberg were all connected with TRIPLE FRONTIER at some point. Little wonder feels less like a passion project than like a movie-star-scheduling puzzle that has finally been solved.
author: OrrChris

text:
Point: JC Chandor is the most underrated director in America (Margin Call, All Is Lost, A Most Violent Year)

Counterpoint: Or possibly not (Triple Frontier)

My review of his new Netflix heist movie: https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2019/03/netflix-triple-frontier-heist-movie-chandor-affleck-review/584878/ … @TheAtlantic
author: OrrChris
